(5) Has the Government undertaken modelling to assess whether it is a disincentive for people receiving the DSP to participate in the labour market when they risk significant loss
of access to income supports; if so, what was concluded; if not, why not.
(6) Has the Government considered improving the security of transition from DSP into employment by reinstating the initial threshold of work from 15 to 30 hours per week;
if so, what was the result of that consideration; if not, why not.
Mr Fletcher: The Minister for Families and Social Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(1) The following answer was provided by Services Australia. The Services Australia Protocol for Engaging People with Disability outlines its commitment to better services and access for people with disability. The protocol is available on the Services Australia website at www.humanservices.gov.au/disabilityprotocol
Services Australia supports people with disability by ensuring access to information via
various channels that assist with their claims for Disability Support Pension (DSP). It does this by:
- using audio and video clips to explain payments and services
- providing accessible transcripts that are available for download and captioned videos
- providing some information in audio, CD, DVD, large print, braille and e–text
- assisting Disability Support Pension customers by providing free interpreters, including
Auslan interpreters
People who are deaf or have a hearing or speech impairment can contact Services Australia using the free Talk to You service or via the National Relay Service.

The Services Australia website, including information about DSP, has been designed to meet the Australian Government standard under the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG). Services Australia aims to meet WCAG 2.0 level AA.
The Services Australia website is the first government website to meet the Plain English Foundation's gold standard for clear communication.
(2) The following answer was provided by Services Australia. As part of its Bilaterial

Management Arrangement with the Department of Social Services, Services Australia has a target of 70 per cent of new DSP claims to be processed within 49 days. Services Australia met that target in 2017–18 and 2018–19.
(3) DSP claimants who are assessed as having 20 points or more under the Tables for the

Assessment of Work-related Impairment for Disability Support Pension (Impairment Tables), but do not have what is termed a 'severe impairment', are required to demonstrate they have tried to improve their work capacity by participation in a Program of Support (POS). A DSP claimant has a severe impairment if the person's impairment is assessed at 20 points or more under the Impairment Tables, of which 20 points or more are assigned under a single Impairment Table.

Generally, a person will have met the POS requirement if they have participated in a Commonwealth funded employment assistance program, such as Disability Employment Services, for at least 18 months within the three years prior to their DSP claim. A person can also be deemed to have met the POS requirement, where they commence a program and it is terminated early, because it is determined they cannot increase their capacity to work due to their impairment.
In 2018-19, around 1,300 claims were rejected because claimants had not met the POS requirements. This represents around 2 per cent of total DSP rejections in 2018-19.
(4) Although an impairment can only be assessed for DSP purposes if the condition

is fully diagnosed, treated and stabilised, a fluctuating or episodic condition with episodes of intermittent impairment may still be considered fully stabilised if it has been fully treated and the impact on ability to work is unlikely to improve significantly within the next two years.

The assessment of Episodic and Fluctuating conditions is built into the legislation. The rules for applying the Impairment Tables (part of the Social Security (Tables for the Assessment ofWork-related Impairment for Disability Support Pension) Determination 2011) state at 11 (4):

"When assessing impairments caused by conditions that have stabilised as episodic or fluctuating a rating must be assigned, which reflects the overall functional impact of those impairments, taking into account the severity, duration and frequency of the episodes or fluctuations as appropriate."
(5) In general, the effects of the income test free area and taper rates mean pensioners are better
off receiving additional income compared to income support alone.

Arrangements currently built into the DSP eligibility criteria seek to encourage and support people to re‑enter and remain in the workforce. Once granted, all DSP recipients are able to engage in paid employment for less than 30 hours a week and still receive a part‑pension, subject to income testing. People who have high earnings from employment or tell Services Australia they are starting work of 30 hours or more a week (paid at least at the minimum wage) can have their DSP suspended (that is, held open) for up to two years. This means, if the person is unable to manage the job or needs to reduce their hours of work because of their disability, they can return to DSP without having to make a new claim. In addition, when returning to work, they retain access to the Pensioner Concession Card for 12 months. This card provides various concessions, including Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme prescriptions at a cheaper rate and access to the lower threshold of the Extended Medicare Safety Net.
(6) Refer to response to question 5.
